**INSTITUTION PALLIATIVE CARE CONSULTATION PATIENT NAME: **NAME[AAA, BBB M] ACCOUNT #: **ID-NUM **ROOM ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY M ZZZ] CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY M ZZZ] DATE OF ADMISSION: **DATE[Jun 17 2006] DATE OF CONSULTATION: **DATE[Jun 19 06] We are asked by Dr. **NAME[YYY ZZZ] to see this patient in consultation. Chief complaint is coping and nausea. HPI: The patient is a **AGE[in 60s]-year-old female, with a past history of heart failure, who is status post recent orthotopic heart transplant in **DATE[Mar] of 2006. Her immediate postoperative course was uncomplicated and she was doing well at home but did have some compliance issues with undergoing a right heart catheterization recently. She was admitted to the hospital on **DATE[Jun 17] after spending seven days sick in bed at home with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, as well as a cough. The patient's work-up thus far has included a chest x-ray that showed no acute cardiopulmonary abnormality. There is a suspicion that she may have CMV pneumonia or CMV GI infection. Today, the patient's main complaint is that of nausea. She states that she cannot keep any of her pills down and she is constantly nauseous. She says that Zofran is not helping. She reports that she was also having watery diarrhea at home, but that has improved somewhat. She denies depression, reports some mild anxiety. Also complaining of a cough and sinus congestion.
The patient denies any problems with the care that she is receiving in the hospital or any conflicts with her physicians or other caregivers. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Ischemic cardiomyopathy status post heart transplant as mentioned in the HPI. 2. COPD. 3. DVT status post IVC filter this admission. 4. History of uterine and cervical cancer status post radiation implant and hysterectomy. 5. CVA with no residual. 6. History of small bowel obstruction in the past. 7. History of arterial insufficiency in her legs. 8. History of a positive PPD, currently being treated with isoniazid. ALLERGIES: NO DRUG ALLERGIES. SOCIAL HISTORY: She lives at home with her daughter. She has two other children that are involved and supportive. She recently lost her husband. She is a former smoker. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Review of systems is negative in detail. MEDICATIONS: Her medications are in the chart and have been reviewed. For antinausea, she is taking Zofran 4 mg p.r.n. For her depression, she is taking Zoloft 100. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On examination, the patient was lying in bed, asleep but easily arousable. HEENT: HEENT examination was positive for some periorbital edema. She had moist mucous membranes. Injected sclerae. Some ecchymosis on the right side of her neck. Cardiovascular: Distant heart sounds. No murmur. She had no lower extremity edema. Lungs: She had distant breath sounds. There were some wheezes on the anterior lung fields, none posterior. No crackles. Normal excursion. Abdomen: Normoactive bowel sounds. Soft, nontender, and nondistended. Skin: There was no rash. Psychiatric: Alert and oriented times three and appropriate. Neurologic: No myoclonus or seizures were noted. Musculoskeletal: No gross joint abnormalities. LABORATORIES: Today she had a lipase of 33 and amylase of less than 30. Her liver function tests were all normal. BUN of 30. Creatinine of 1.2. She had a chest x-ray that was clear. IMPRESSION AND PLAN: Problem #1: Nausea. The etiology of this is unclear but possibly secondary to a CMV GI infection. Her iron is probably exacerbating this. She is not responding to Zofran. We will discontinue Zofran, hold her iron tablets, and start Haldol 0.5 q.12 and 0.5 as a p.r.n. Problem #2: Coping and compliance. The patient has been agreeable to see our behavior medicine psychologist and she will see her on Monday. Problem #3: Depression and anxiety. The patient appears to be well-controlled on her Zoloft, and we will continue this. We will continue to follow.
